name: Syria
currentCrisisSummary:
Following the sudden collapse of the Assad regime in Dec 2024, Syria enters a fragile transition, remaining a **shattered state** enduring catastrophic suffering inflicted through years of war. A transitional government grapples with authority over a territory fractured by armed factions and **occupied by foreign powers** (Turkey, US, Russia).

The 2011 popular uprising was transformed into an **internationalised proxy war** by competing powers pursuing **geopolitical agendas**. This **external interference** fuelled violence, prolonged suffering, and caused the **collapse of state and society**. Millions are displaced, infrastructure ruined, and most depend on aid, leaving Syria vulnerable to new forms of **economic coercion** masked as reconstruction.

imperialRoot.legacy:
The modern Syrian state is a product of **imperial design**. The 1916 **Sykes-Picot Agreement** and subsequent **French Mandate** created **artificial borders**. France used '**divide-and-rule**' tactics, exacerbating sectarian tensions. This fragmented national identity and laid **structural foundations** for conflict.

During the **Cold War**, Syria became a **client state** of the Soviet Union, entrenching an **authoritarian state structure** and setting the stage for intense **foreign interventions** after 2011.

historicalContext.title: Pre-War Neoliberal Reforms
historicalContext.description: A catalyst for the 2011 uprising was the **economic policy** of the preceding decade. Encouraged by the **IMF**/**World Bank**, Assad implemented **neoliberal 'reforms'**: dismantling subsidies, **privatising public assets**, opening to **foreign capital**. This enriched a **crony-capitalist class** while creating mass unemployment and poverty. Protests were partly a rebellion against this inequality.

historicalContext.title: Internationalised Proxy Warfare
historicalContext.description: The conflict exemplifies a domestic uprising hijacked by **external forces**. Seeking **regime change**, the **US, Turkey, Saudi Arabia, Qatar** supported a fragmented opposition. In response, **Russia and Iran intervened** decisively to preserve the government and secure **strategic interests**. This became a multi-sided **proxy war** fought for **geopolitical dominance**.

historicalContext.title: Fragmentation and the War on Terror
historicalContext.description: War chaos, fuelled by the 2003 **US invasion of Iraq**, enabled ISIS's rise. The **US-led intervention** against ISIS (including devastating air campaigns) resulted in the de-facto **US military occupation** of northeast Syria. This further fragmented the country, placed resources under **US-backed proxy forces**, adding another layer of **imperial entanglement**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: Over half a million estimated deaths (at least 300k civilians) from indiscriminate bombing, sieges, and atrocities in the **proxy war**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population
humanitarianImpact.description: Est. 16.7 million require aid, suffering consequences of **state collapse** engineered by war and **foreign interference**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Food Insecurity
humanitarianImpact.description: Est. 12.9 million endure food insecurity, driven by war destroying agriculture and **sanctions** crippling the economy.

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 7.2 million internally displaced by bombardment and offensives conducted by the regime and **foreign powers**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugee Crisis
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 6.8 million refugees (world's largest) driven abroad by extreme violence from the **internationalised conflict**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Education System Decimated
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 2.4 million children denied education as schools destroyed by bombing or unsafe due to conflict.

humanitarianImpact.title: Extreme Poverty
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 90% live below poverty line due to war's destruction, compounded by crippling **unilateral sanctions**.

timeline.event: **Sykes-Picot Agreement**: Britain and France sign a secret treaty to partition the Ottoman Middle East. The accord draws artificial lines on the map, creating the colonial mandates for Syria and Iraq and embedding inter-sectarian and regional tensions that persist to this day.
**French Mandate**: France defeats a local Arab army at the Battle of Maysalun and imposes its colonial mandate, creating the modern Syrian state.
**The 'Corrective Movement'**: Hafez al-Assad seizes power in a coup, consolidating the rule of the Ba'ath Party and establishing a highly centralised authoritarian state.

**Hama Massacre**: The government of Hafez al-Assad brutally crushes an Islamist uprising in the city of Hama, killing tens of thousands of civilians. The event establishes a precedent for the state's capacity for extreme internal violence and shapes its ruthless response to the 2011 uprising.
**Inheritance of Power**: Bashar al-Assad succeeds his father and begins a period of limited economic liberalisation that exacerbates social inequality.
**Popular Uprising**: Inspired by the Arab Spring, mass protests demanding democratic reforms begin in Daraa and spread across the country. The government responds with lethal force.
**Russian Military Intervention**: Russia launches a major, direct military intervention on behalf of the Syrian government, decisively altering the course of the war.

**US Caesar Act Enacted**: The US imposes a devastating regime of sanctions targeting any entity involved in Syria's reconstruction. The act functions as a form of economic warfare that collectively punishes the civilian population and cripples the post-war economy.
**'Deterrence of Aggression' Offensive**: A coalition of opposition forces launches a surprise offensive in northwest Syria, leading to the rapid collapse of government defensive lines.

**Fall of Damascus & End of Assad Regime**: On December 8, opposition forces enter Damascus with little resistance as the 54-year rule of the Assad family collapses. Bashar al-Assad flees the country, marking a seismic shift in the conflict.

**Transitional Period**: Following the regime's collapse, a transitional government is formed to manage state institutions, navigate the complex security environment, and begin the process of political reconstruction amidst ongoing foreign military presences.

advocacy.title: Support a Syrian-Led Transition
advocacy.description: Support a Syrian-led, inclusive political transition that protects the rights of all communities and prevents a new cycle of authoritarianism or civil conflict.

advocacy.title: End All Foreign Occupations
advocacy.description: Demand the complete withdrawal of all foreign military forces to restore Syrian sovereignty.

advocacy.title: Lift Unilateral Sanctions
advocacy.description: Advocate for the lifting of broad unilateral sanctions to allow for reconstruction and the revival of the civilian economy.

advocacy.title: Support Truth and Accountability
advocacy.description: Push for international support for truth and accountability commissions to address the war crimes committed by the former regime and all other parties.

advocacy.title: Uphold the Right of Return
advocacy.description: Uphold the right of return for Syrian refugees by demanding safe, voluntary, and dignified conditions.

reading.title: *Burning Country: Syrians in Revolution and War*
reading.description: Robin Yassin-Kassab & Leila Al-Shami centre Syrian voices, telling the story of the uprising and its descent into proxy war from a grassroots perspective.

reading.title: *The Impossible Revolution: Making Sense of the Syrian Tragedy*
reading.description: Yassin al-Haj Saleh, a leading Syrian leftist intellectual, offers a profound analysis of the Assad regime's nature and the revolution against it.

reading.title: *Syria After the Uprisings: The Political Economy of State Resilience*
reading.description: Joseph Daher provides a critical political economy analysis, linking pre-war neoliberal policies to the uprising and the regime's structure.
